Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: The following method describes the identification of candidate immunogenic peptides through their ability to recall an immune T-cell activation from peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) of individuals with defined HLA–peptide restrictions that have been previously exposed to the antigen. Isolated PBMCs are plated out at a concentration of 1×106 cells/ml in a 200 μl medium and incubated overnight to reduce cytokine gene expression due to cell manipulation. After starving, cells are either directly stimulated with individual peptides or not stimulated and incubated from 3 to 12 h according to experimental conditions. Quantitative real-time PCR (qrt-PCR) is performed on reverse-transcribed complementary DNA (cDNA) from total RNA that is isolated from peptide-cultured PBMCs. To perform high quality qrt-PCR, primers and probes are designed to span exon–intron junctions in order to prevent amplification of genomic DNA and to produce amplicons <150 base pairs (bp). Real-time monitoring of fluorescent emission from the cleavage of sequence specific probe by the nuclease activity of Taq polymerase (TaqMan method) defines threshold cycles during exponential phases of amplification. Standard curves of copy numbers of the gene of interest are normalized using as reference copy numbers of control genes.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: This method is based on the ability of peptides to recall an immune T-cell activation. Levels of cytokine gene expression in response to ex vivo antigen recall are used to detect epitope-specific HLA-restricted T cells. The main rationale for using ex vivo techniques is based on the notion that PBMCs that bear HLA determinants relevant to the HLA–peptide restriction under investigation carry memory T cells that have been exposed in vivo to the antigen of interest, either naturally upon viral infection (1) or following specific vaccination procedures (2). Thus, this sensitive assay might be able to identify these responses without in vitro cell expansion. The stronger the immune response induced in vivo against epitopes from the selected antigen, the easier and more specific should be the detection of memory T-cell activities. The magnitude of cytokine gene transcription upon peptide stimulation, as analyzed by qrt-PCR in serologically positive donors, represents an accurate index of the biological events following T-cell reactivation triggered by specific MHC–peptide complexes (3). The sensitivity and specificity of this method are decisive in unravelling the fine relationship between MHC–peptide associations and specific immune responses, enabling the characterization of more than one HLA restriction for one individual epitope.

Section1.Heading: Methods
Section1.Para: The methods described below outline: (1) Cell collection and culture and peptide handling, (2) RNA extraction and complementary DNA (cDNA) synthesis, (3) design of primers and probes for quantitative rt-PCR (qrt-PCR) and their reconstitution, 4) quantitative rt-PCR performance.

Section2.Heading: Cells and Peptides
Section2.Para: Collection, culture and handling of the cells and peptide design and reconstitution are described in Sects. 3.1.1–3.1.3.

ItemContent.Para: Whole blood from either healthy donors or patients is collected in 7 ml heparinized tubes (Sarstedt) by venipuncture.

Transfer 10 ml of whole blood into a 50 ml Falcon tube and add 30 ml PBS to reach a total of 40 ml (Fig.
8.1
a).
Fig. 8.1.
Ficoll–Hypaque density gradient. (a) Transfer 10 ml of whole blood into a 50 ml Falcon tube and add 30 ml PBS to reach 40 ml total. (b) Mix well by shaking. (c) Introduce 10 ml pipette containing Ficoll fluid and flow fluid slowly from the bottom of the tube. (d) Centrifuge and aspirate the leukocyte ring and the 5 ml fluid (serum) overlaying the gradient interface.

Mix well by shaking and then add 10 ml Ficoll–Hypaque by introducing a 10 ml pipette containing Ficoll fluid (Fig.
8.1b
and c).
Centrifuge at 1,950 rpm for 20 min at 20°C without brake.
Aspirate the leukocyte ring with a 10 ml pipette carefully avoiding collecting the underlaying Ficoll fluid (toxic for cells).
Transfer the cells in a new 50 ml Falcon tube and fill it up to 50 ml with PBS. Mix well.
Centrifuge at 1,250 rpm for 15 min (long-wash) at 20°C, discard the supernatant and re-suspend the pellet in fresh PBS (50 ml total).
Repeat the washing at 1,250 rpm for 10 min (short wash) at 20°C.
Re-suspend cells (PBMCs) in RPMI complete medium (see Section 2), count them and adjust them at 1×106cells/ml.

Section3.Heading: Peptide Synthesis, Reconstitution, and Storage
Section3.Para: Peptides in powder are reconstituted in a DMSO solution ranging from 20 to 100% depending on the solubility of the peptides. Reconstituted peptides are generally stocked in 1.5 ml cryo-vials and stored at +4°C during their use or stored at –20°C for long term storage. Peptide-stocks at 10 mg/ml concentrations are usually preferred.

ItemContent.Para: PBMCs re-suspended in RPMI complete medium at the final concentration of 1×106cells/ml are now plated out in 96-U bottom wells plate.
A total amount of 200 μl RPMI medium (2×105 cells total) is plated in each well.

The number of total loaded wells will depend on the sample condition (number of peptides) you wish to analyze plus eventual positive controls (at least one) and the negative control (cells left unstimulated) (Fig.
8.2
a).
Fig. 8.2.
(a) Plate out PBMCs in 96-U bottom wells plate at the final amount of 2×105cells total (200 μl RPMI medium). Rest plated cells over-night in incubator (37°C, 5% CO2, 90% humidity) to minimize cytokine gene expression. (b) After starving, add directly in the well the candidate peptide at the final concentration of 1 μM. Re-incubate cells for 3 h. (c) Harvest cells transferring them in collection tubes.
After plating, cells are rested for 18 h (normally over-night resting) in incubator (37°C, 5% CO2, 90% humidity) to minimize cytokine gene expression due to cell manipulation.
Cells are then re-incubated (37°C, 5% CO2, 90% humidity) for an extra 3-h period (see Note 1).
Remove supernatant by aspirating carefully (see Note 2).

Section2.Heading: Genomic RNA and DNA
Section2.Para: Total RNA extraction for each sample is performed following the RNeasy Mini Kit (QIAGEN) instructions (see Note 3): (a) disruption of the cells, (b) washing of the cell lysate, (c) elution of total RNA from disrupted cells. Up to 1 μg of total RNA is synthesized into cDNA through: (a) RNA-oligo (dT) primers pre-heating, b) RT-PCR mixture holding, (c) cDNA synthesis by reverse transcription, (d) RNA clean up.

ItemContent.Para: Add 350 μl of RTL complete lysis buffer (10 μl β-ME per 1 ml RTL buffer; prepare solution before use) in the 2 ml collection tube containing pelleted cells (see Section 3.1.3 . and Note 4).
Disrupt cells by gently vortexing and then add 350 μl 70% ethanol by mixing.

Transfer the lysate into the RNeasy Mini Spin column (maximum loading volume 700 μl) and spin at 16,000 rpm (thereafter referred to as high speed) for 15 s at +4°C. RNA is retained in the white membrane of the RNeasy Mini Spin columns.
Discard the flow-through, reuse the collector tube and wash membrane one time with 700 μl RW1 washing buffer (high speed, 15 s at +4°C).
Change the collector tube and wash membrane with 500 μl RPI buffer containing four volumes of 96–100% ethanol at high speed for 15 s at +4°C.
Discard the flow-through, reuse the collector tube and repeat this wash for 2 min.
Discard the collector tube and leave residual ethanol evaporating from the RNeasy Mini Spin column for few seconds.
Place RNeasy Mini Spin columns in a new 2 ml collector tube and pipette 25 μl RNAse free water (or DEPC water) in the middle of the membrane of the tube.
Spin at high speed for 1 min at +4°C.
Repeat the elution with extra 25 μl RNAse free water (same spinning as above).
Put RNA eluate on ice, mark it and immediately use it for cDNA synthesis or store it at –70°C until use (see Note 5).

Section3.Heading: Complementary DNA (cDNA) Synthesis
Section3.Para:
Each sample of cDNA is synthesized from the corresponding RNA by following four steps:
1.
First, up to 1 μg of total RNA is incubated at 70°C for 10 min with 1 μl oligo (dT) primers (0.5 μg/μl) in a final volume of 12 μl (RNA volume is defined depending on its concentration; adjust with DEPC water to reach the 12 μl final volume).
2.
After cooling at 4°C for 1 min, add 7 μl of RT-PCR mix to the sample (2 μl RT buffer 10×, 2 μl 25 mmol MgCl2, 1 μl dNTP 10 mmol, 2 μl 1 M DTT) and hold the mix at 42°C for 5 min.
3.
Then, add 1 μl Superscript RT II (50 U/μl) to each sample and synthesize cDNA at 42°C for 50 min and at 70°C for 15 min.
4.
Clean up for possible RNA contamination is performed by incubating samples with 1 μl RNase at 37°C for 20 min.
5.
Synthesized cDNA should be stored at +4°C (or –20°C for a longer storage)

Section2.Heading: Quantitative Real-Time PCR Primers and Probe
Section2.Para: The paragraph includes: (a) Probe labeling for TaqMan method, (b) Primers and probe design, (c) Primers and probe reconstitution.

Section3.Heading: Probe Labeling for TaqMan Method
Section3.Para: The concept of real-time PCR relies of the detection of PCR products as they accumulate. Current qrt-PCR systems are based on sets of primers and fluorogenic probes. The fluorescence signal increases with each PCR amplification cycle. The PCR cycle in which fluorescence reaches a threshold value of ten times the standard deviation of baseline fluorescence emission is called the cycle threshold (C t) and it is inversely proportional to the starting amount of target genetic material (4). TaqMan Method indicates a signal generation throught the degradation of a fluorogenic probe by employing the 5’–3?’ nuclease activity of Taq DNA polymerase (5). TaqMan probes are labeled at the 5’-end with the reporter dye molecule FAM (6-carboxyfluorescein; emission λ max=518 nm) and at the 3’-end with the fluorescent quencher dye molecule TAMRA (6-carboxytetramethylrhodamine; emission λ max=582 nm) (see Note 6).

Section3.Heading: Primers and Probe Design
Section3.Para:
Cytokine gene primers and probe for qrt-PCR (TaqMan method) are designed by Primer Express software but some guidelines are necessary to reach high quality qrt-PCR performance (2, 6).
1.
Primers should be between 15 and 20 nucleotides long and not overlapping with probe complementary sequences in order to cover an amplicon with a length ≤ 150 base pairs (bp). Give prevalence of better probes over primers.
2.
Primers melting temperature (T m) should be 58–60°C and probes T m should be 68–70°C.
3.
Primers and probes guanosin/cytosin (G/C) content should be between 20 and 80% (avoiding G to be on the 5’end and having C content higher than G content).
4.
To avoid hairpins or loops within primers and probes, the five nucleotides at 3’end of each primer should have no more than two Gs or Cs.
5.
Avoid also runs of identical nucleotides within primers.

Section3.Heading: Primers and Probes Reconstitution
Section3.Para: Primers are usually shipped in a lyophilized state (unless differently requested) while probes are more often shipped in 1× TE solution. The best performance for cytokine gene expression using qrt-PCR assay is achieved by using primers and probes at specific final concentration. In our experience, optimized concentration are: 400 nM for primers (see Note 7) and 200 nM for probes (1, 7). It is thus suggested to prepare both primers and probes working stock solutions in DEPC water (or 1× TE) at 20 μM for each primer and 12.5 μM for each probe (see Sects. 3.4.1 and 3.4.4).

Section2.Heading: Performing Quantitative Real-Time PCR
Section2.Para: This paragraph reports indications to precisely perform qrt-PCR for cytokine gene expression analysis: (a) cDNA amplification and quantification (b) tenfold serial dilutions of known gene concentrations for standard curve generation (c) standard curve validation for absolute quantification analysis (see Note 8), (d) TaqMan Master Mix preparation and thermal cycler parameters definition for both standard and test cDNA qrt-PCR reactions.

Section3.Heading: cDNA Amplification and Quantification for Standard Curve Generation
Section3.Para:
Complementary DNA from a positive control template is generated by reverse transcription using a technique identical with the one used for the preparation of test cDNA (Section 3.2.2). Cytokine genes are amplified by means of regular PCR using the same primers designed for qrt-PCR (Section 3.3.2).
1.
PCR mix: 25 μl HotStart mix (QIAGEN), 1 μl forward primer at 20 μM (400 nM), 1 μl reverse primer at 20 μM (400 nM), 1 μl cDNA, 22 μl DEPC water; final volume 50 μl.
2.
PCR parameters:
10 min at 95°C
30 s at 95°C, 30 s at 60°C and 2.5 min at 72°C (40 cycles)
5 min at 72°C
3.
Quantify amplified cDNA (double strand) in μg/ml by spectrophotometry (OD=260).

Section3.Heading: Amplified Gene Serial Dilutions for Standard Curve
Section3.Para:
In order to create a curve by tenfold standard dilutions at known gene concentration, the number of copies of amplified cDNA (standard cDNA) from a positive control template has to be calculated. To perform it you should know:
1.
The concentration of your amplified cDNA (OD260 reading usually in μg/ml)
2.
The molecular weight (MW) of your amplicon
3.
The Avogadro number (number of molecules in 1 mole = 6.023×1023)

Example for calculation of IFNγ molecules after DNA amplification:
1.
OD260 = 461 μg/ml → 4.61 μg/10 μl (4.61 μg → 4.61×10–6 g).
This is your starting concentration for serial dilutions (see below).
2.
Molecular weight (MW) of IFNγ amplicon = 36,492 g/M
3.
4,61×10–6 g/36,492 g/M → 1.26×10–10 M
4.
1.26×10–10 M * 6.023×1023 → 7.61×1013 molecules
5.
7.61×1013 is equivalent (~) to 1×1014 molecules
You have approximately 10
14
molecules in 10 μl of your solution.
6.
Make tenfold serial dilutions adding 10 μl of your starting solution (1014 molecules) to 90 μl DEPC water to reach the final volume of 100 μl. Repeat dilutions as below illustrated (10 μ sample + 90 μl DEPC water) and stop with the last solution of 103 molecules (Fig.
8.3 ).
Fig. 8.3.
Serial dilutions preparation. Make tenfold serial dilutions adding 10 μl of your starting solution (i.e., 1014 molecules) to 90 μl DEPC water to reach the final volume of 100 μl. Repeat dilutions as above illustrated (10 μl sample + 90 μl DEPC water) and stop with the last solution of 103 molecules. To test your standard for cytokine gene expression, use dilutions from 108 to 103.
7.
Use cDNA serial dilutions for qrt-PCR test or store them at +4°C (or –20°C for a longer storage).

Section3.Heading: Quantitative rt-PCR Reactions
Section3.Para:
Quantitative rt-PCR reactions for both standard and test cDNA are conducted as reported below. To test your standard for cytokine gene expression, use dilutions from 108 to 103.
1.
Prepare a TaqMan Mix: 12.5 μl of 1× TaqMan Universal Master Mix®, 0.5 μl forward primer at 20 μM (400 nM), 0.5 μl reverse primer at 20 μM (400 nM), 0.4 μl probe at 12.5 μM (200 nM), 10.1 μl DEPC water; final volume 24 μl.
2.
Load 96-well optical reaction plate (Applied Biosystems) with 24 μl TaqMan Mix in triplicate for each sample you wish to run. Avoid bubbles.
3.
Add cDNA to each of the three wells related to the sample you wish to run.
4.
Close tightly the plate.
5.
Centrifuge the plate at 2,000 rpm for 2 min at +4°C.
6.
Thermal cycler parameters for 25 μl final volume (24 μl TaqMan Mix + 1 μl cDNA) using either an ABI prism 7700, 7900, or 7500FAST Sequence Detection System are:
a.
2 min at 50°C
b.
10 min at 95°C
c.
15 s at 95°C (denaturation) and 1 min at 60°C (annealing/extension) for 45 cycles.

Section3.Heading: Standard Curve Validation and Gene Copy Number Extrapolation (Absolute Quantification Method)

ItemContent.Para:
Standard curve generation is necessary for the extrapolation of gene copy numbers (absolute quantification of gene copy numbers). Serial dilutions of the amplified gene (standard cDNA) at known concentration (108–103) are thus tested by qrt-PCR to determine the standard curve PCR for slope of −3.32, efficiency = 1. It indicates doubling of template after each PCR cycle). Linear regression analysis of each standard should show a high correlation (R 2 ≥ 0.99) (Fig.
8.4 ). Extrapolation of copy number of each given gene (x) is conducted following this formula: x = 10(unknown sample Ct–y intercept)/slope
Fig. 8.4.
β-Actin standard curve plots for calculation of PCR efficiency and quantitation. A tenfold serial dilution of a positive control template is used to generate the standard curve. The resulting threshold cycle (C t) values for each input amount of template are plotted as a function of the log10 concentration of input amounts. The resulting slope of the line fitted to the data is used to determine the PCR efficiency. Optimal standard curves are based on PCR amplification efficiency as demonstrated by the slope of the standard curve equation. Linear regression analysis of all standard curves should show a high correlation (R 2 coefficient ≥0.99) to be considered suitable for gene levels quantitative analysis. The function that defines this slope is also used to calculate the amount of unknown samples. Most real-time PCR instruments have software that can automatically compute the amount of template of an unknown sample from a standard curve. However, it can be done manually by putting the observed C t value for an unknown sample into the following formula: (observed C t–y intercept)/slope (1).

Number of copies of an endogenous control gene (reference gene; i.e., β-actin) is also quantified. For each experimental sample, the value of both target and reference genes are extrapolated from the respective standard curve equation.
The target value is divided by the reference gene value to obtain normalized targets (independent from amount of starting material).

Section1.Heading: Notes

ItemContent.Para: Due to differential HLA/peptide binding capacity and cytokine kinetics, incubation time could be extended to 12 h (8).

To minimize cell handling when working with several samples, a direct centrifugation of the 96-well plate (5 min, 1,250 rpm, 20°C) after 3-h incubation could be performed and the supernatant can be vigorously flicked out.
For a higher quality RNA extraction, the RNA extraction Triazol method could be also chosen.
RLT complete lysis buffer (RTL + β-ME) can be stored at room temperature for up 1 month. RTL lysis solution (RTL complete lysis buffer + pellet) could be stored at –70°C for months.
Due to the instability of RNA at room temperature, all RNA extraction steps and centrifugations should be performed at 0–4°C (ice temperature). Thaw RNA out on ice when it comes from –70°C storage.

More reporter dyes are available to label TaqMan probes: TET™, JOE™, VIC™. By using probes labeled with different fluorochromes characterized by unique emission spectra, more genes can be analyzed simultaneously within a given sample (multiplex qrt-PCR) (9).
Depending on the efficiency of the primers, their optimized concentration should range between 400 and 800 nM
